Thank you for initiating the debate on whether court stenographers are necessary. After careful consideration of your reason, which is that a transcript produced by a competent reporter is irreplaceable, and not having one may sacrifice justice, I understand your perspective. However, I must respectfully disagree with your claim that court stenographers are necessary. 

While it is true that a transcript produced by a competent reporter can be very valuable in providing an accurate record of courtroom proceedings, it is not the only means by which justice can be achieved. In today's technologically advanced world, there are alternative methods available for recording and documenting court proceedings. 

For example, the use of digital audio recording systems has become a common practice in many courtrooms. These systems are capable of capturing high-quality audio recordings of all proceedings, which can later be transcribed if needed. Digital recordings provide an objective and precise account of what occurred during the trial, eliminating the possibility of human error that may occur with stenography.

Additionally, advancements in artificial intelligence technology have allowed for the development of sophisticated speech-to-text transcription software. These programs can accurately transcribe spoken words into written text, further reducing the need for human stenographers.

It is important to note that the cost and availability of court stenographers can be a limitation in some regions. Hiring and training qualified stenographers can be expensive and may result in delays in court proceedings. By utilizing alternative recording methods and transcription technology, courts can achieve efficiency and cost savings while still maintaining accurate documentation of proceedings.

In conclusion, while court stenographers have traditionally played a significant role in capturing and documenting court proceedings, I believe that their necessity is being challenged by technological advancements. The availability of digital audio recording systems and speech-to-text transcription software provides viable alternatives that can achieve similar results with greater efficiency and cost-effectiveness. Therefore, I respectfully disagree with the claim that court stenographers are necessary.
